headline: 10 Investment Must Reads for This Week (Feb. 3, 2026)
summary: Nearly 1,000 active ETFs launched in 2025, almost double the previous record. What some macro indicators are saying about markets. These are among the investment must-reads we found this week for financial advisors.

headline: US brokers may charge fee from ETF managers as commission-free trading takes a toll
summary: U.S. brokerage firms and custodians may seek distribution fees from managers of exchange-traded funds, J.P. Morgan said, marking a ​possible crucial shift in the country's $13.5 trillion ETF market.  Platforms such as Robinhood attracted millions of retail investors with zero trading fees and simple mobile apps, pulling customers and trading volume away from traditional brokerages.  To combat the shift in the competitive landscape, legacy players such as Fidelity and Charles Schwab have raced ⁠to win over clients by ‌slashing trade commissions to as low as zero dollars for exchange-traded funds.

To combat the shift in the competitive landscape, legacy players such as Fidelity and Charles Schwab have raced ⁠to win over clients by ‌slashing trade commissions to as low as zero dollars for exchange-traded funds.

headline: RBC Capital Projects 37%-38% Margins for Invesco (IVZ) in 2026/2027
summary: Invesco Ltd. (NYSE:IVZ) ranks among the biggest publicly traded asset managers. On January 28, RBC Capital reduced its price target for Invesco Ltd. (NYSE:IVZ) to $33 from $35 while retaining an Outperform rating on the company’s shares. The adjustment comes after Invesco’s fourth-quarter results, with analyst Kenneth Lee identifying the company’s 2026 expense estimate as […]

headline: Invesco Dividends And Buybacks Put Capital Returns In Focus
summary: Invesco (NYSE:IVZ) announced its latest quarterly dividend and preferred dividends, supported by current free cash flow. The company also continued its share buyback program, alongside commentary on dividend sustainability. The board reiterated its focus on maintaining dividend payments and issued section 19 notices to clarify distribution sources. Invesco is a global asset manager, so its results are closely tied to client assets, fee structures, and broader market activity. For income...

headline: 5 Must-Read Analyst Questions From Invesco’s Q4 Earnings Call
summary: Invesco’s fourth quarter was marked by revenue growth that surpassed Wall Street expectations, yet the market reacted negatively due to a sharp and unexpected decline in operating margin. Management cited higher-than-anticipated expense growth and increased technology investments as key factors behind the margin compression.
